Query 1.title: Video from Beach Party in Kyiv Proves War in Ukraine Is a Hoax ...
Query 1.snippet: Aug 7, 2023 ... While browsing the Instagram profile on Aug. 6, 2023, we found various videos and pictures shared as stories — i.e. clips that would disappear ...

content.content: "The war in Ukraine is FAKE," one social media user commented. -------------------------------------------------------------- ### Published Aug. 7, 2023 Claim: A video that went viral in August 2023 showed a beach party in Kyiv, proving that the war in Ukraine is a hoax. What's True The video is authentic and was captured on Aug. 6, 2023, at Fifty Beach Club in Kyiv. What's False Neither the party nor the video of it proves that the war in Ukraine is fake or a hoax. Kyiv is located more than 300 miles from the active front line, where Ukrainian and Russian troops were fighting as of the date this article was published. In August 2023, a video on social media that allegedly documented a party at a beach club in Kyiv, Ukraine. Users shared the clip as purported evidence that the was a hoax, or that supporters of Ukraine were exaggerating the conflict's threat to the country. "The war in Ukraine is FAKE," one tweet , sharing the video that showed people drinking and talking in swimsuits around a pool. > The war in Ukraine is FAKE. > > — Stew Peters (@realstewpeters) "There is currently a party at the Beach Club in war-torn Kyiv Ukraine, please keep the people of Ukraine in your prayers," another social media user with apparent sarcasm. ! **(Twitter user @dom\_lucre)** With a similar tone, another social media user , "BREAKING: The Biden administration has approved $300 Million in additional aid in the form of Beach Towels, Sun Screen and Sun Glasses," making light of U.S. funding to help Ukraine defeat Russia. All in all, the in question gained millions of views. In addition to the above-displayed tweets, it was reposted on various and across Russian-speaking social media platforms. While it was true the footage authentically depicted a beach ... [Content truncated]

ContentScore.Newness Justification: Published on August 7, 2023, it's very current and addresses the misinformation directly.
ContentScore.Relevance Justification: The evidence directly deals with the claim that the video proves the war in Ukraine is a hoax, making it very relevant.

A video of Ukrainians partying at a beach club has gone viral amid a debate overseas about whether or not the United States and the West should support any for the war. Since Russia launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022, the U.S. has committed to more than $60 billion in , the most of any of Kyiv's Western allies. The clip, posted by user @shadyftw on Monday, shows hundreds of people partying around the pool bar at Fifty Beach Club in Kyiv with the caption, "Beach club in Kyiv during the war." has amassed more than 4.1 million views as of Thursday afternoon. Social media users quickly flooded the comments to cast doubt about the state of the war between Ukraine and Russia, asking "Why are we all panicked and worried when it is party season over there" and joking "Well, at least the Americans are footing the bill." ! Query 2.title: For Ukrainians abroad like me, watching the war from afar is ...
Query 2.snippet: Mar 18, 2022 ... Ilya Timtchenko is a freelance writer and a former business editor and reporter for the Kyiv Post. March 18, 2022 at 4:00 a.m. EDT.

content.content: clockThis article was published more than 2 years ago We do what we can to help It was around 10 p.m. in Cambridge, Mass., when Russia decided to launch rockets against my home country on Feb. 23. I remember sitting at my desk staring, frozen, watching from afar what was happening to my peace-loving, newly democratic Ukraine. The missile explosions in the heart of Kyiv’s residential districts meant people’s families, apartments, relationships were being ruined — people I know and have known all my life. I knew the invasion was imminent, based on the numerous warnings coming from U.S. intelligence and my own assessment of the situation. I had been a journalist based in Kyiv since 2014, and I’m now in my first year at the Harvard Kennedy School. Just during winter break, I spent a few weeks in festive Kyiv visiting former colleagues and friends. But it is one thing to “know” and hope that world leaders can somehow magically stop a tyrant, and it is another thing to see your home being invaded. In an instant, 44 million people went through a massive collective trauma. A fledgling democracy, so inspiring to so many, full of hope and verve, has been attacked in such a cowardly and malicious manner. Stop imagining Putin’s overthrow. Fantasies won’t help Ukraine. I had a similar experience when I was studying in the U.S. for my undergraduate degree in 2013 and 2014 when Ukraine’s Euromaidan revolution broke out. I remember the shock and emotions that came from seeing the first deaths: Ukrainians being mercilessly beaten and shot on the streets of Kyiv by the horde of police and Berkut special forces that were an extension of the Kremlin’s puppet regime under Ukraine’s then-president Viktor Yanukovych. I remember the lack of sleep, the urge to ... [Content truncated]

QA.Question: What evidence supports the presence of a beach party in Kyiv during the Ukraine war?
QA.Answer:
The evidence supporting the presence of a beach party in Kyiv during the Ukraine war includes the following points:

1. **Authentic Video Evidence**: A video that went viral on social media captured scenes from a beach party at the Fifty Beach Club in Kyiv. This video was recorded on August 6, 2023, and depicts people enjoying themselves in a beach club atmosphere, including scenes of individuals sunbathing and socializing. An article from Snopes confirms the authenticity of this video and acknowledges its viral spread, despite its usage as supposed evidence of the war being a hoax [Query 1_evidence_1].

2. **Public Reaction and Context**: The same video sparked significant public discussion and backlash, with many social media users expressing disbelief about the situation in Ukraine, as they saw the video as contradictory to the narratives of ongoing conflict. This reaction further highlights that a beach party did indeed occur in Kyiv, giving a glimpse into life amidst the war. Newsweek reported on the video, noting that it showed "hundreds of people partying around the pool bar" at the same beach club, reinforcing the idea that life continued to some extent in urban areas like Kyiv [Query 1_evidence_2].

3. **Statements from Locals**: The context provided by users posting the videos indicates a conscious effort to present a balanced view of life in Ukraine during the war. Edward, one of the users who posted videos, mentioned aiming to showcase different aspects of life in Ukraine, which suggests that such social activities are, in fact, occurring [Query 1_evidence_2]. 

Given this evidence, we can confidently state that the beach party in Kyiv did occur amidst the ongoing conflict. However, while the presence of the party is documented, it does not negate the reality of the war itself.
